Sports Personality of the Year

26/11/2012

With the shortlist for Sports Personality of the Year finally released, Beth Jakubowski assesses each candidate's claim to the trophy (Thumbnail credit Andy Murray in action in the men's US Open final. Image: mbevis via flickr Creative Commons.)

Image by

By undefined undefined

So we finally get a glimpse at who could possibly be crowned Sports Personality of the Year 2012. What a list it is as well. This summer's Olympic heroes are out in force and this year, the race seems more open than ever before. Here are my thoughts on each candidate. Andy Murray (Tennis): 76 years of pain, toil, despair and dismay, 76 years of frustration and 'nearly there's', 76 years until Great Britain got Andy Murray. His performance in the US Open Final was majestic. It's been a long standing joke that when Murray wins he's British, but when he loses he's Scottish. Well Andy, I think we can safely say you're always going to be classed as British from now on. As a gold medallist, a Wimbledon finalist and a grand slam winner, no arguments from me on this candidate. Jessica Ennis (Athletics): No one entered London 2012 under more pressure than Ennis. She was the face of London 2012, but not just the face for Britain to see, she was the face for the world to see. Ennis didn't just win a gold medal in London 2012; she triumphed to a gold medal. As a multi disciplined athlete, these medals are the hardest to win, and in the two days of solid competition, no one even came close to Ennis. David Weir (Athletics): Four gold medals in the Paralympics is an astonishing achievement. It's not just his sporting achievements that warm me to the man; it's his quiet, humble, charming personality off the track. He's everything a sportsman should be. He's a role model. The 'Weir Wolf' is one of the athletes who smashed the glass ceiling of disabled sport this summer. Mo Farah (Athletics): Mo Farah's greatest sporting achievement this year isn't a gold medal in the 10,000 metres, and it isn't even a gold medal in the 5,000 metres...it's when he introduced the mo-bot to the world. In all seriousness though, Farah is an athlete after everyone's heart. Double gold in distance running is a feat precious few had achieved, and Farah is part of an elite club. The message from the public is very simple regarding Farah, I need not use superlative after superlative to describe him, because it very simply boils down to one thing. We love Mo. Sarah Storey (Cycling): It would have been impossible to overlook the sheer genius of Sarah Storey and her four gold medals. For me, she's done the equivalent of what Weir has done for the Paralympics. She's shattered the glass ceiling. With two gold medals on the track and two gold medals on the road, Storey dominated cycling throughout the London games. Looking back on her career as a whole though is phenomenal, eleven gold medals, eight silver medals and three bronze medals. She quite simply, deserves this nomination Katherine Grainger (Rowing): Seeing as rowing was the second largest contributor to the Team GB medals table it's fitting that they get a spot on the shortlist. Grainger endured an agonising three Olympics prior to London. But these games were different, these games, Grainger walked away a gold medallist. Silver wasn't her calling anymore, it was gold all the way for one of the best female rowers Britain has produced. Ben Ainslie (Sailing): The King of the Olympic seas, Ben Ainslie thoroughly deserves a spot on this list. He is easily one of Britain's greatest ever Olympians. He famously declared to his opposition in a very Hulk like fashion, 'you won't like me when I'm angry', and no Ben they did not. After a shaky start Ainslee proved that for starters he likes to give his fans a heart attack, and for another, he's a fighter. It takes ten days to win one gold medal in the Finn class, Ainslee has won four. Now that is some achievement. Ellie Simmonds (Swimming): It's impossible to leave this girl out. She, like Jess Ennis, went into the Paralympics as the face of the games. Under enormous pressure to give a performance as impressive as Beijing, Simmonds knew she had to do something very special. Boy, did she deliver. She is incredibly loveable to the public; her two gold medals at the London games were sensational and cemented her status as a Paralympian great...at just 17 years old. Nicola Adams (Boxing): She could very much be the dark horse of this competition. I admit, when I first compiled my list of who should be nominated, I did not include Adams. But in all consideration, she absolutely deserves a place on the shortlist. She became the first women boxer to win a gold medal in the 51kg event and while she was at it she beat the world number one. Adams is an inspiration to female boxers everywhere, and her sunny personality endeared her to the public during the Olympics. Adams could very well walk away with a prize at this year's SPOTY. Sir Chris Hoy (Cycling): Now here's one I may not entirely agree with. Chris Hoy is undoubtedly a legend. Passing Sir Steve Redgrave's medal tally this Olympics was quite an achievement, but personally, I believe there was a track cyclist who had a better games than Sir Chris. Jason Kenny, by Hoy's own admission, was the stand out Team GB performer in the velodrome. Kenny went in under huge personal pressure; he replaced Hoy in the individual sprint, a friend, teammate and roommate. Gold was his only option. Hoy has already won SPOTY, and he won it after his greatest ever Olympic performance. For me, Kenny should have got the nod. Hoy will forever be a legend, but this year, Kenny was the star. Rory McIlroy (Golf): In an Olympic year, especially a home Olympic year, the inclusion of a golfer is completely beyond me. The number of people McIlroy kept off this list is astonishing. Think of Alastair Brownlee, Greg Rutherford, Laura Trott, and Johnny Peacock. Yes, he is the world number one, but this is a year in which the slogan was 'inspire a generation', I fail to see how McIlroy has done that. This is the one nomination I totally and completely disagree with. There's only one nominee left. This is the man I think should be walking away with the Sports Personality of the Year prize. For me, no one even comes close to this man's sheer brilliance. Arise Sir Wiggo I love a sports star that's uncensored. Bradley Wiggins says what he thinks and he doesn't care who he annoys in the process. And we love it. The first British man to win the Tour de France and he followed that up a week later with a time trial gold medal. He struggled in the past with self belief, he struggled with being a leader, and he struggled with accepting his potential. But this year, he embraced all of that and he started the patriotic revolution. People who didn't even care about the Tour de France previously were suddenly gripped by the drama, the excitement and the will power displayed by these remarkable athletes. It's a gruelling twenty one days of riding. They say that 90% of cycling is in your head, that when your muscles are screaming at you to stop and every fibre of your being is on fire, you find the will to carry on. I believe that Sir Wiggo dug deeper than any other athlete on this list to win the Tour de France. He's the only rider to have ever won the Paris-Nice, the Tour of Romandy and Criterium du Dauphine in one season. To then bring home a gold medal is an unparalleled achievement. He's a man who spectacularly conquered the track and the road. This should be Sir Wiggo's SPOTY award. It would be a travesty if he walked away with nothing.
